title: Stack Ranking Collaboration Kill
context: Companies implement forced ranking (stack ranking) to identify top performers and manage out low performers. Every review cycle, managers must rank employees on a curve — a fixed percentage get top ratings, a fixed percentage get bottom ratings. The system was popularized by Jack Welch at GE and adopted across tech. The result: employees compete against each other instead of against the market. Collaboration dies because helping a colleague succeed means you rank lower. The system optimizes for individual performance metrics while destroying the teamwork that actually drives organizational success.
hypothesis: Forced ranking identifies top performers and motivates everyone to improve.

chain.root: Implement forced ranking / stack ranking system

effects.label: Collaboration becomes irrational — helping others hurts your ranking

children.label: Engineers hoard information that could help teammates
Mentoring junior employees becomes a cost with no reward
Cross-team projects avoided because credit is hard to claim

effects.label: Political behavior replaces productive behavior
effects.impact: Employees optimize for visibility, not impact

children.label: Self-promotion and credit-claiming become survival skills
Employees choose high-visibility projects over high-impact ones
Sabotaging colleagues becomes rational under the incentive structure

effects.label: Forced curve creates artificial losers
effects.impact: Bottom 10% must exist even on excellent teams

children.label: High-performing teams still must label someone as underperforming
Managers game the system — hire sacrificial candidates for the bottom slot
Morale collapses when good performers get low ratings due to the curve

effects.label: Top performers leave — they have options and hate the politics
effects.impact: Voluntary attrition among top quartile increases 20-30%

children.label: Best engineers go to companies without stack ranking

dontIf: Your company's success depends on cross-team collaboration
You're in a talent market where top performers have many options
ifYouMust: Rank teams, not individuals — incentivize collective performance
Include collaboration and mentoring as explicit ranking criteria
Allow managers to rate entire teams as high-performing without forced distribution
Separate development feedback from compensation decisions

alternatives.name: Peer feedback systems
alternatives.note: 360-degree feedback focused on growth, not ranking — collaboration becomes visible and rewarded

alternatives.name: Team-based incentives
alternatives.note: Reward team outcomes rather than individual rankings — aligns incentives with how work actually happens

alternatives.name: Continuous feedback
alternatives.note: Regular 1:1 coaching replaces annual ranking — addresses performance issues in real-time

seo.description: Stack ranking kills collaboration — knowledge sharing drops 30-50%, political behavior replaces productive work, and top performers leave 20-30% faster. Microsoft's lost decade proved it.
